Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

An adult unicycle rider accelerates to the right. A unicycle has a single wheel but is otherwise similar to a bicycle, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A rider with sufficient practice is able to accelerate while leaning forward to maintain their balance.

The external forces exerted on the rider-unicycle system while balance is maintained and the system accelerates to the right are shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The frictional, normal and gravitational forces exerted on the system’s center of mass <math alttext="open parentheses C M close parentheses" overflow="scroll"> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>CM</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> are <math alttext="F sub lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="F sub N" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math>, and <math alttext="F sub g" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi>g</mi></msub></math>, respectively. The arrows represent only the direction of each force and begin at the point at which each force is exerted on the system.
content.question:
(a) An observer of the rider on the unicycle correctly makes the following claim:

“For the rider to maintain their balance, the rider’s center of mass must be located to the right of the point at which the wheel is in contact with the ground.”

Using appropriate physical principles, justify this claim. Include qualitative reasoning beyond referencing equations in your answer.

frqParts.text:
(a) An observer of the rider on the unicycle correctly makes the following claim:

“For the rider to maintain their balance, the rider’s center of mass must be located to the right of the point at which the wheel is in contact with the ground.”

Using appropriate physical principles, justify this claim. Include qualitative reasoning beyond referencing equations in your answer.

For a given rightward acceleration of magnitude <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math>, the rider-unicycle system’s center of mass is located a constant distance <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> above the ground and a constant distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> to the right of the point at which the wheel is in contact with the ground, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>.
(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> in terms of <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference tables.

Consider the case where a small child rides on the unicycle. In this case, at a given rightward acceleration of magnitude <math alttext="a sub child" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>child</mi></msub></math> where the child maintains balance, the child-unicycle system’s center of mass is a constant distance <math alttext="one half H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>H</mi></math> above the ground and a constant distance <math alttext="one half D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>D</mi></math> to the right of the point at which the wheel is in contact with the ground.
(c) Indicate if <math alttext="a sub child" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>child</mi></msub></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math>?

Using the expression derived in part (b), justify your answer.
